misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No bug / correct control-flow for range classification
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that checking ranges from highest to lowest with an if / else-if chain will correctly map a numeric grade into exactly one letter category.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no gap here: in Java, an if / else-if chain executes the first true condition and skips the rest, so ordering the thresholds from highest to lowest correctly enforces the intended ranges (90+ => A, else 80+ => B, etc.).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None (produces correct output for all integer grades, including the sample input 85 => B).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No bug / correct conditional range logic
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that checking only the lower bounds in descending order (>= 90, else >= 80, else >= 70, else >= 60, else) correctly partitions the 0–100 input range into the required letter-grade buckets.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap here: in an if/else-if chain, once a condition matches, later conditions are skipped, so descending lower-bound checks correctly implement the intended intervals (e.g., 85 fails >=90, then matches >=80 → B).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None for valid inputs in the stated domain (0–100).
